ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basics of random walks, Brownian motion, diffusion, application of these to biological sensing. Some fluid dynamics and applications to the circulatory system. Discussion of Kleiber's law, the repressilator (and simulating it with the Gillespie algo), kinetic proofreading, the active machinery in the inner ear. The Ising model and simulating it with MCMC.
Understanding probabilistic models as related to biology, kinetics, sensory processing, modeling simulations via code, reading scientific papers, attending biophysics conference etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The topics covered in this course were interesting, but it was a bit disorganized. It could be improved if it had more structure. The bar for mathematical knowledge coming in was too low, so too much time was spent on catching up on various techniques and not enough time on really digging in.

Strengths: Mactha was a great professor and made it easy to understand high-level ideas, study halls helped to supplement class, TA's were very helpful

Weaknesses: Did not provide notes on canvas
bad lecturer, please post notes, and make exam pre more easy

Strengths: coding learning, interesting material

weaknesses: the professor wasn't really communicative with his TAs about things, there were quite a few mistakes on the homework and the professor wasn't very good at admin stuff for the class. Additionally, while Slack was used relatively affectively, if an announcement was made that was highly important for the whole class, it should be announced using canvas. The professor also did not respond readily to emails and was a little confusing in how he taught the material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class maintained collaborative study halls. The notes were not posted for this class and the teaching was done on a blackboard.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to students interested in applications of physics to living systems. It won't necessarily blow your mind on its own; you have to come in with some interest or you'll likely get bored. I think you could either skate by in this class and get nothing out of it, or put some thought into the things we discuss and have a good experience.
Yes, this course is manageable even for undergrads if you put enough work into it. It's a great way to collaborate with grad students and covers engaging material.

Yes, I would, tentatively. If you have some background in biology and statistical mechanics, it is much easier to take this course. Also its not too hard of a class just a little confusing. The professor and TAs are really nice but again, the Professor can explain things pretty confusingly.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live and recorded lecture with live study halls
I used recorded lectures more towards the end of the semester.
